{{marriage|[[Harlee McBride]]|1985}} | notable_work = [[John Munch]] on ''[[Homicide: Life on the Street]]'' and ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' }} '''Richard Jay Belzer''' (born August 4, 1944){{cite web | url =http://www.filmreference.com/film/65/Richard-Belzer.html | title = Richard Belzer Biography (1944–) | publisher = FilmReference.com | accessdate = October 7, 2012}} is an American stand-up [[Stand up comedian|comedian]], author,{{Cite web|url=http://authors.simonandschuster.com/Richard-Belzer/46217925/books|title=Richard Belzer's Books|publisher=www.simonandschuster.com}} and actor. He is best known for his role as BPD Detective, NYPD Detective/Sergeant and DA Investigator [[John Munch]],{{cite news|first=Richard|last=Belzer|work=[[The Huffington Post]]|title=Munch Madness|date=2013-10-16|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/richard-belzer/munch-madness_b_4111628.html}} whom he has portrayed as a regular cast member on the [[NBC]] [[police drama]] series ''[[Homicide: Life on the Street]]''{{cite news|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|title=Farewell, Detective Munch: Richard Belzer’s Cop Character Leaves SVU|first=Melissa|last=Locker|date=October 16, 2013|url=http://entertainment.time.com/2013/10/16/farewell-detective-munch-richard-belzers-cop-character-leaves-svu/}} and ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'', as well as in guest appearances on a number of other series. He portrayed the character for 23 years from 1993 to 2016. ==Early life and education== Belzer was born in [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]], the son of Frances and Charles Belzer, a tobacco and candy retailer. He grew up in a Jewish{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/14/arts/television/14rich.html|title=Two Funny Guys With the Same Name, but Not the Same Jokes|last=Steinberg|first=Jacques|date=14 January 2009|work=The New York Times|accessdate=22 March 2011}} family. He described his mother as frequently [[child abuse|physically abusive]], and declared that his comedy career began when trying to make his mother laugh in order to distract her from abusing him and his brother.{{cite news| url=https://nypost.com/2014/07/30/older-brother-of-law-order-actor-jumped-to-his-death/ | work=New York Post | first1=Dana | last1=Sauchelli | first2=Kevin | last2=Fasick | title=Richard Belzer's brother jumps to his death | date=July 30, 2014}} After graduating from [[Fairfield Warde High School]], Belzer worked as a reporter for the ''[[Connecticut Post|Bridgeport Post]].'' Belzer attended [[Dean College]], which was then known as [[Dean Junior College]], in [[Franklin, Massachusetts]], but was expelled.{{cite web|url=http://www.southjersey.com/articles/?articleid=3474|title=Richard Belzer - SouthJersey.com|author=|date=|website=www.southjersey.com|accessdate=19 March 2018}} He worked at a variety of jobs, including sales and as a [[census]] taker. ==Career== ===Stand-up=== After his first divorce, Belzer relocated to [[New York City]], moved in with singer [[Shelley Ackerman]], and began working as a stand-up comic at [[Pips (comedy club)|Pips]], [[The Improv]], and [[Catch a Rising Star (comedy clubs)|Catch a Rising Star]]. He participated in the Channel One comedy group that satirized television and became the basis for the cult movie ''[[The Groove Tube]],'' in which Belzer played the costar of the ''ersatz'' TV show "The Dealers."{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0071583/ |title=The Groove Tube |website=IMDb |publisher=Amazon |access-date=September 4, 2016}} Belzer was the audience warm-up comedian for ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''{{cite web |url=http://www.aarp.org/entertainment/television/info-09-2010/interview_richard_belzer.html |title='Uncontrollable Wit’: An Interview with Law & Order's Richard Belzer |last1=Getlen |first1=Larry |date=September 24, 2010 |website=AARP |publisher=AARP |access-date=September 4, 2016}} and made three guest appearances on the show between 1975 and 1980.{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0001938/?ref_=fn_al_nm_1 |title=Richard Belzer |website=IMDb |publisher=Amazon |access-date=September 4, 2016}} He also opened for musician [[Warren Zevon]] during his tour supporting the release of his album ''[[Excitable Boy]]''.{{Citation needed|date=October 2012}} ===Film=== In the late 1970s and early 1980s, Belzer became an occasional film actor. He is noted for small roles in ''[[Fame (1980 film)|Fame]]'', ''[[Café Flesh]]'', ''[[Night Shift (film)|Night Shift]]'', and ''[[Scarface (1983 movie)|Scarface]]''. He appeared in the [[music videos]] for the [[Mike + The Mechanics]] song "[[Taken In]]" and for the [[Pat Benatar]] song "Le Bel Age", as well as the [[Kansas (band)|Kansas]] video "Can't Cry Anymore". He appeared in ''[[A Very Brady Sequel]]'' as an [[Los Angeles Police Department|LAPD]] detective. ===Radio=== In addition to his film career, Belzer was a featured player on the ''[[National Lampoon Radio Hour]]'' with co-stars [[John Belushi]], [[Chevy Chase]], [[Bill Murray]], [[Gilda Radner]], and [[Harold Ramis]], a half-hour comedy program aired on 600 plus U.S. stations from 1973 to 1975.{{cite web|work=[[NPR]]|title='The National Lampoon Radio Hour'|date=November 17, 2003|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1505048}} Several of his sketches were released on National Lampoon albums, drawn from the Radio Hour, including several bits in which he portrayed a pithy call-in talk show host named "[[Dick Ballentine]]". In the late 1970s, he co-hosted ''Brink & Belzer'' on 660AM [[WFAN|WNBC]] radio in New York City.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aNECAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA33&lpg=PA33&dq=richard+belzer+disk+jockey&source=bl&ots=lbYgEIugfq&sig=Qs1c8HlvHVk7jNjrVNdTAGlW1H4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjllaDhsqTTAhXMyFQKHcAUBiUQ6AEILzAB#v=onepage&q=richard+belzer+disk+jockey&f=false|title=New York Magazine|first=New York Media|last=LLC|date=2 July 1979|publisher=New York Media, LLC|accessdate=19 March 2018|via=Google Books}} He has been a frequent guest on ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]''. Following the departure of [[Randi Rhodes]] from [[Air America Radio]], Belzer guest-hosted the afternoon program on the network.{{cite news |url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/04/10/richard-belzer-to-fill-in_n_96098.html | first = Danny | last = Shea | date = 18 April 2008 | title = Richard Belzer to Fill in During Randi Rhodes' Air America Time Slot |accessdate = 14 June 2014 |work = Huffington Post}} ===Television=== In the 1990s, Belzer appeared frequently on television. He was a regular on ''[[The Flash (1990 TV series)|The Flash]]'' as a news anchor and reporter. In several episodes of ''[[Lois & Clark: The New Adventures of Superman]],'' he played [[Inspector William Henderson]]. He followed that with starring roles on the [[Baltimore]]-based ''[[Homicide: Life on the Street]]'' (1993–99) and the [[New York City|New York]]–based ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' (1999–2013), portraying police detective [[John Munch]] in both series. [[Barry Levinson]], executive director of ''Homicide'', said Belzer was a "lousy actor" in audition when he read lines from the script for "[[Gone for Goode]]", the first episode in the series.{{Cite news |last=Mendoza |first=Manuel |title=Revisit 'Life on the Street' |work=[[The Dallas Morning News]] |date=2003-06-11 |location=[[Dallas]], [[Texas]] |page=1E}} Levinson asked Belzer to take time to reread and practice the material, then read it again. At his second reading, Levinson said Belzer was "still terrible", but that the actor eventually found confidence in his performance.{{Cite video | people=[[Barry Levinson|Levinson, Barry]] |date=2003|title=Homicide Life on the Street – The Seasons 1 & 2 |medium=DVD audio commentary |publisher=[[A&E Television Networks|A&E Home Video]]}} In addition, Belzer has played Munch in episodes on seven other series and in a sketch on one talk show, making Munch the only fictional character to appear on eleven different television shows played by a single actor{{Citation needed|date=June 2017}}. These shows were on six different networks: * ''[[Homicide: Life on the Street]]'' ([[NBC]]) * ''[[Law & Order]]'' ([[NBC]]) * ''[[The X-Files]]'' ([[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]) * ''[[The Beat (TV series)|The Beat]]'' ([[UPN]]) * ''[[Law & Order: Trial by Jury]]'' ([[NBC]]) ** Belzer's appearance on ''Trial by Jury'', which aired April 15, 2005, made him the third actor ever to play the same character in six different prime time TV series. The other two actors are [[John Ratzenberger]] and [[George Wendt]], who played [[Cliff Clavin]] and [[Norm Peterson]], respectively, in ''[[Cheers]]'' (1982–93); ''[[St. Elsewhere]]'' (1985); ''[[The Tortellis]]'' (1987); ''[[Wings (NBC TV series)|Wings]]'' (1990); ''[[The Simpsons]]'' (1994); and ''[[Frasier]]'' (2002). * ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'' ([[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]) * ''[[The Wire (TV series)|The Wire]]'' ([[HBO]]) * ''[[30 Rock]]'' ([[NBC]]) ** The characters are watching a ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'' episode; a scene shot for ''30 Rock'' * ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' ([[NBC]]) * ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'' ([[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]) * ''[[Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt]]'' ([[Netflix]]), in which he played a John Munch-like character on a fictional ''Law & Order'' spinoff. In March 2016, executive producer Warren Leight announced Belzer would return to reprise the role in a May 2016 episode of ''Law & Order: Special Victims Unit'', titled "Fashionable Crimes".{{cite news| url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/03/22/law-order-svu-richard-belzer-munch-returning|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]] | title= 'Law & Order: SVU': Richard Belzer returning as Detective Munch|first=Natalie|last=Abrams|date=March 22, 2016|accessdate=March 22, 2016}} Belzer portrayed Det. Munch for 22 consecutive seasons on ''Homicide'' (7 seasons) and ''Law & Order: SVU'' (15 seasons), which exceeded the previous primetime live-action record of twenty consecutive seasons held by [[James Arness]] (who portrayed [[Marshal Matt Dillon]] on ''[[Gunsmoke]]'' from 1955 to 1975) and [[Kelsey Grammer]] (as Dr. [[Frasier Crane]] on ''[[Cheers]]'' and ''[[Frasier]]'' from 1984 to 2004). Belzer appeared in several of [[Comedy Central]]'s televised broadcasts of [[New York Friars' Club|Friars Club]] roasts. On June 9, 2001, Belzer himself was honored by the New York [[New York Friars' Club|Friars Club]] and the Toyota Comedy Festival as the honoree of the first-ever roast open to the public. Comedians and friends on the dais included Roastmaster [[Paul Shaffer]]; [[Christopher Walken]]; [[Danny Aiello]]; [[Barry Levinson]]; [[Robert Klein]]; [[Bill Maher]]; ''SVU'' costars [[Mariska Hargitay]], [[Christopher Meloni]], [[Ice-T]], and [[Dann Florek]]; and ''Law & Order''{{'s}} [[Jerry Orbach]]. At the December 1, 2002, roast of [[Chevy Chase]], Belzer said, "The only time Chevy Chase has a funny bone in his body is when I fuck him in the ass." {{cite web |url = http://www.slate.com/id/2074752 | title = The Meanest Roast|accessdate = 2 December 2002 |work = Slate}} Belzer voiced the character of Loogie for most of the episode of ''[[South Park]]'' titled "[[The Tooth Fairy Tats 2000]]".{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} He and [[Brian Doyle-Murray]] were featured in the tenth-season premiere of ''[[Sesame Street]]''.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}} ===Author=== Belzer believes there was a [[John F. Kennedy assassination conspiracy theories|conspiracy to assassinate President John F. Kennedy]]{{cite news |last=Birnbaum |first=Robert |date=November 18, 2013 |title=JFK Is Still Dead: Another Historiographical Moment |url=http://www.vqronline.org/books/jfk-still-dead-another-historiographical-moment |newspaper=Virginia Quarterly Review |location=Charlottesville, Virginia |accessdate=December 22, 2014}} and has written four books discussing [[conspiracy theories]]: ''UFOs, JFK, and Elvis: Conspiracies You Don’t Have to Be Crazy to Believe''; ''Dead Wrong: Straight Facts on the Country’s Most Controversial Cover-Ups''; ''Hit List: An In-Depth Investigation into the Mysterious Deaths of Witnesses to the JFK Assassination''; and ''Someone Is Hiding Something: What Happened to Malaysia Airlines Flight 370?''{{cite journal |last=Elias |first=Marilyn |date=Winter 2013 |title=Conspiracy Act |url=http://www.splcenter.org/get-informed/intelligence-report/browse-all-issues/2013/winter/conspiracy-act |journal=Intelligence Report |publisher=Southern Poverty Law Center |issue=152 |accessdate=December 22, 2014}} ''Dead Wrong'' and ''Hit List'' were written with journalist David Wayne and reached [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''The New York Times'' Best Seller list]]. ''Someone Is Hiding Something'' was also written with David Wayne as well as radio talk show host [[George Noory]]. Belzer's long-time character, John Munch, also is a believer in conspiracy theories, including the JFK assassination. ==Personal life== Belzer's first two marriages were to Gail Susan Ross (1966–72) and boutique manager Dalia Danoch (1976 – c. 1978), both of which ended in divorce. In 1981 in [[Los Angeles]] he met 31-year-old [[Harlee McBride]], a divorcee with two daughters,{{cite news | url = http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-02-20/features/1997051147_1_richard-belzer-john-munch-mcbride | last = Hiaasen | first = Rob | title = Detective Mensch: A dark comic with a sweetheart of a soul, Richard Belzer has found a new life with 'Homicide' | work = [[The Baltimore Sun]] | date = February 20, 1997 | accessdate = October 7, 2012 | archivedate = October 7, 2012 | archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6BFN0vf8V?url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-02-20/features/1997051147_1_richard-belzer-john-munch-mcbride | deadurl = no | df = }} Bree Benton and Jessica.Hiaasen, [http://articles.baltimoresun.com/1997-02-20/features/1997051147_1_richard-belzer-john-munch-mcbride/3 p/ 3] McBride, who had been seen in ''[[Playboy]]'' magazine four years earlier in that year's sex-in-cinema feature, in conjunction with ''Young Lady Chatterley'',{{cite journal | title = Sex Stars of 1977| work =[[Playboy]] | date= December 1977}} was appearing in [[TV commercials]] for [[Ford]] motors and acting in free theater, when she met Belzer at the suggestion of a friend. The two married in 1985.{{Cite news | url = http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20110060,00.html | title = Richard Belzer: His Wit Honed by Anger, He's a Comic Who Has Gone from Stand-Up to Homicide | work = [[People (magazine)|People]] | date = March 29, 1993 | volume =39 | issue= 12 | first = Peter | last= Castro}} RE Ross: "In 1971, a year before the end of his six-year marriage to Gail Susan Ross...." RE Danoch: "In 1976. Belzer worked himself into a second marriage with Dalia Danoch, a boutique manager, but it ended in divorce less than two years later." Belzer survived [[testicular cancer]] in 1983. His HBO special and comedy CD ''Another Lone Nut'' pokes fun at this medical incident as well as his status as a well-known [[conspiracy theorist]]. On March 27, 1985, days prior to the inaugural [[WrestleMania I|WrestleMania]], Belzer requested on his [[cable TV]] talk show ''Hot Properties'' that [[Hulk Hogan]] demonstrate one of his signature wrestling moves. After being asked by Belzer several times, Hogan put Belzer in a front chin-lock, which caused Belzer to pass out.{{YouTube|i7n_SHrK408}} When Hogan released him, Belzer hit his head on the floor, sustaining a laceration to the scalp that required a brief hospitalization.{{cite news | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,141573,00.html | title = Hype! Hell Raising! Hulk Hogan! | authorlink=Richard Corliss | first= Richard | last = Corliss |work= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | accessdate=2008-07-08 | date=June 24, 2001 | archivedate= June 29, 2011 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110629010403/http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,141573,00.html}} Belzer sued Hogan for $5 million and settled out of court. On October 20, 2006, on ''[[Bubba the Love Sponge]]'', it was claimed{{By whom|date=October 2012}} (with Hogan in the studio) that the settlement totaled $5 million, half from Hogan and half from wrestling promoter [[Vince McMahon]]. During his June 23, 2008, appearance on [[Sirius Satellite Radio]]'s ''The Howard Stern Show'', Belzer suggested that the settlement amount was closer to $400,000.{{cite web|url=http://www.howardstern.com|title=Howard Stern|author=|date=|website=Howard Stern|accessdate=19 March 2018}}{{Failed verification|date=January 2014}} He used the incident in his [[HBO]] special ''Another Lone Nut'' in his stand-up routine. Belzer's older brother, Leonard Belzer (age 73) committed suicide in the early morning hours of July 30, 2014, by jumping from the roof of the New York City luxury apartment building in which he had resided. Belzer’s father had also committed suicide in 1968. Belzer is a cousin of actor [[Henry Winkler]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/PhotoGallery/Surprising-Celebrity-Family-1073313/1073326 |title=Henry Winkler Pictures, Richard Belzer Photos - Photo Gallery: Surprising Celebrity Family Ties |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher=[[TV Guide]] |accessdate=October 31, 2014}} ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- !
